informal_statement:
Define a positive integer $n$ to be \emph{squarish} if either $n$ is itself a perfect square or the distance from $n$ to the nearest perfect square is a perfect square. For example, $2016$ is squarish, because the nearest perfect square to $2016$ is $45^2 = 2025$ and $2025 - 2016 = 9$ is a perfect square. (Of the positive integers between $1$ and $10$, only $6$ and $7$ are not squarish.)

For a positive integer $N$, let $S(N)$ be the number of squarish integers between $1$ and $N$,
inclusive. Find positive constants $\alpha$ and $\beta$ such that
\[
\lim_{N \to \infty} \frac{S(N)}{N^\alpha} = \beta,
\]
or show that no such constants exist.
informal_solution: Prove that the limit exists for $\alpha = \frac{3}{4}$ and equals $\beta = \frac{4}{3}$.
formal_statement:
theorem putnam_2016_b2
(squarish : â„¤ â†’ Prop)
(hsquarish : âˆ€ n, squarish n â†” IsSquare n âˆ¨ âˆƒ w : â„¤, IsSquare |n - w ^ 2| âˆ§ âˆ€ v : â„•, |n - w ^ 2| â‰¤ |n - v ^ 2|)
(S : â„¤ â†’ â„•)
(hS : S = fun n â†¦ {i âˆˆ Finset.Icc 1 n | squarish i}.card)
(p : â„ â†’ â„ â†’ Prop)
(hp : âˆ€ Î± Î², p Î± Î² â†” Î± > 0 âˆ§ Î² > 0 âˆ§ Tendsto (fun N â†¦ S N / (N : â„) ^ Î±) atTop (ğ“ Î²))
: ((âˆ€ Î± Î² : â„, ((Î±, Î²) = ((3 / 4, 4 / 3) : â„ Ã— â„ ) â†” p Î± Î²)) âˆ¨ Â¬âˆƒ Î± Î² : â„, p Î± Î²) :=
sorry

            âˆƒ j k : Fin n, j < k âˆ§ Â¬(P t j âˆ£ P t k) âˆ§ P (t + 1) j = Nat.gcd (P t j) (P t k) âˆ§ P (t + 1) k = Nat.lcm (P t j) (P t k) âˆ§

informal_statement: Let $f_1,\dots,f_{10}$ be bijections of the set of integers such that for each integer $n$, there is some composition $f_{i_1} \circ f_{i_2} \circ \cdots \circ f_{i_m}$ of these functions (allowing repetitions) which maps 0 to $n$. Consider the set of $1024$ functions $\mathcal{F}=\{f_1^{e_1} \circ f_2^{e_2} \circ \cdots \circ f_{10}^{e_{10}}\}$, $e_i=0$ or $1$ for $1 \leq i \leq 10$. If a coin occupies the square $(i,j)$ with $i \leq m-1$ and $j \leq n-1$ and the squares $(i+1,j)$, $(i,j+1)$, and $(i+1,j+1)$ are unoccupied, then a legal move is to slide the coin from $(i,j)$ to $(i+1,j+1)$. (IsLegalMove_def : âˆ€ coins1 coins2,

    âˆƒ i j, i < m - 1 âˆ§ j < n - 1 âˆ§

      !coins2 i j âˆ§ !coins2 (i + 1) j âˆ§ !coins2 i (j + 1) âˆ§ coins2 (i + 1) (j + 1) âˆ§

        â†’ coins1 i' j' = coins2 i' j'))
(IsLegalSeq : List (â„• â†’ â„• â†’ Bool) â†’ Prop)
(IsLegalSeq_def : âˆ€ seq, IsLegalSeq seq â†” seq.length â‰¥ 1 âˆ§ seq[0]! = initcoins âˆ§ (âˆ€ i < seq.length - 1, IsLegalMove seq[i]! seq[i + 1]!))

informal_statement:
Let $n$ be a positive integer. Set $a_{n, 0} = 1$. For $k \geq 0$
choose an integer $m_{n, k}$ uniformly at random from the set
$\{1, 2, \ldots, n\}$, and let
$$a_{n, k+1} = \begin{cases}
a_{n, k} + 1 & \text{if } m_{n, k} > a_{n, k} \\
a_{n, k} & \text{ if } m_{n, k} = a_{n, k} \\
a_{n, k} -1 & \text{if } m_{n, k} < a_{n, k} \end{cases}$$.
Let $E(n)$ be the expected value of $a_{n, n}$. Determine
$\lim_{n \to \infty} E(n)/n$.
informal_solution: Show that the limit is $\frac{1 - e^{-2}}{2}$.

theorem putnam_2024_b4

    [MeasureSpace Î©]
    [IsProbabilityMeasure (â„™ : Measure Î©)]
    (m a : â„• â†’ â„• â†’ Î© â†’ â„¤)
    (hâ‚€ : âˆ€ n > 0, a n 0 = 1)
    (hâ‚ : âˆ€ n k, 0 < n â†’ pdf.IsUniform (m n k) (Set.Icc 1 n) â„™ (ProbabilityTheory.uniformOn <| Set.Icc 1 n))
    (hâ‚‚ : âˆ€ n k Ï‰, 0 < n â†’
      a n (k + 1) Ï‰ =
        if m n k Ï‰ > a n k Ï‰ then
          a n k Ï‰ + 1
        else if m n k Ï‰ = a n k Ï‰ then
          a n k Ï‰
        else
          a n k Ï‰ - 1)
    (hâ‚ƒ : ProbabilityTheory.iIndepFun inferInstance m.uncurry â„™) :
    Filter.Tendsto (fun n => (âˆ« Ï‰, a n n Ï‰ : â„) / n) Filter.atTop (ğ“ (((1 - rexp (- 2))/2) : â„ )) :=
  sorry

informal_statement: Let $n$ be an even positive integer.   (âˆ‘ k, âˆ‘ l, (if (colors k l = 0) then (nums k l) else 0)) = (âˆ‘ k, âˆ‘ l, (if (colors k l = 1) then (nums k l) else 0)) :=

informal_statement: Let \( \mathbb{Z}^n \) be the integer lattice in \( \mathbb{R}^n \). Two points in \( \mathbb{Z}^n \) are called neighbors if they differ by exactly 1 in one coordinate and are equal in all other coordinates. For which integers \( n \geq 1 \) does there exist a set of points \( S \subset \mathbb{Z}^n \) satisfying the following two conditions? \begin{enumerate} \item If \( p \) is in \( S \), then none of the neighbors of \( p \) is in \( S \). \item If \( p \in \mathbb{Z}^n \) is not in \( S \), then exactly one of the neighbors of \( p \) is in \( S \). \end{enumerate}

  (1 â‰¤ n âˆ§ âˆƒ S : Set (Fin n â†’ â„¤),
    (âˆ€ p âˆˆ S, âˆ€ q, neighbors p q â†’ q âˆ‰ S) âˆ§ (âˆ€ p âˆ‰ S, {q âˆˆ S | neighbors p q}.encard = 1))

informal_statement: Assume that the system of simultaneous differentiable equations \[y' = -z^3, z' = y^3\] with the initial conditions $y(0) = 1, z(0) = 0$ has a unique solution $y = f(x), z = g(x)$ defined for all real $x$. Suppose that some arcs $w_1,\dots,w_k$ have the property that $Z=\frac{1}{k}\sum_{j=1}^k Z(w_j)$ and $N=\frac{1}{k}\sum_{j=1}^k N(w_j)$ are both integers. Prove that there exists an arc $w$ with $Z(w)=Z$ and $N(w)=N$.

(Z N : Fin n Ã— Fin (n + 1) â†’ â„¤)

(Zsum Nsum : â„¤)
(npos : n â‰¥ 1) (kpos : k â‰¥ 1)
(hZ : âˆ€ w, Z w = âˆ‘ l : {x : Fin n | x < w.2}, if (circle (w.1 + l) = 0) then 1 else 0)
(hN : âˆ€ w, N w = âˆ‘ l : {x : Fin n | x < w.2}, if (circle (w.1 + l) = 1) then 1 else 0)
(Zle1 : âˆ€ w w', w.2 = w'.2 â†’ |(Z w : â„¤) - Z w'| â‰¤ 1)
(hZsum : Zsum = ((1 : â„) / k) * âˆ‘ j : Fin k, Z (ws j))
(hNsum : Nsum = ((1 : â„) / k) * âˆ‘ j : Fin k, N (ws j)) :
âˆƒ w, Z w = Zsum âˆ§ N w = Nsum :=

informal_statement:
Let $\mathbf{S} = \{(a,b) | a = 1, 2, \dots,n, b = 1,2,3\}$.
A \emph{rook tour} of $\mathbf{S}$ is a polygonal path made up of line segments connecting points $p_1, p_2, \dots, p_{3n}$ in sequence such that
\begin{enumerate}
\item[(i)] $p_i \in \mathbf{S}$,
\item[(ii)] $p_i$ and $p_{i+1}$ are a unit distance apart, for
$1 \leq i <3n$,
\item[(iii)] for each $p \in \mathbf{S}$ there is a unique $i$ such that
$p_i = p$.
\end{enumerate}
How many rook tours are there that begin at $(1,1)$
and end at $(n,1)$?
informal_solution: Show that the number of rook tours is $0$ if $n = 1$ and $2 ^ {n - 2}$ if $n \geq 2$.

theorem putnam_2005_a2
(n : â„•)
(npos : n > 0)
(S : Set (â„¤ Ã— â„¤))
(unit : â„¤ Ã— â„¤ â†’ â„¤ Ã— â„¤ â†’ Prop)
(rooktour : (â„• â†’ â„¤ Ã— â„¤) â†’ Prop)
(hS : S = prod (Icc 1 (n : â„¤)) (Icc 1 3))
(hunit : unit = fun (a, b) (c, d) â†¦ a = c âˆ§ |d - b| = 1 âˆ¨ b = d âˆ§ |c - a| = 1)
(hrooktour : rooktour = fun p â†¦ (âˆ€ P âˆˆ S, âˆƒ! i, i âˆˆ Icc 1 (3 * n) âˆ§ p i = P) âˆ§ (âˆ€ i âˆˆ Icc 1 (3 * n - 1), unit (p i) (p (i + 1))) âˆ§ p 0 = 0 âˆ§ âˆ€ i > 3 * n, p i = 0)
: ({p : â„• â†’ â„¤ Ã— â„¤ | rooktour p âˆ§ p 1 = (1, 1) âˆ§ p (3 * n) = ((n : â„¤), 1)}.encard = ((fun n â†¦ if n = 1 then 0 else 2 ^ (n - 2)) : â„• â†’ â„• ) n) :=

informal_statement:
A function $f$ is convex on $[0, 1]$ if and only if $$f(su + (1-s)v) \le sf(u) + (1 - s)f(v)$$ for all $s \in [0, 1]$.
Let $S_t$ denote the set of all nonnegative increasing convex continuous functions $f : [0, 1] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that $$f(1) - 2f\left(\frac{2}{3}\right) + f\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) \ge t\left(f\left(\frac{2}{3}\right) - 2f\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) + f(0)\right).$$

    (S : â„ â†’ Set (â„ â†’ â„))
    (P_def : âˆ€ t f, P t f â†” f 1 - 2*f (2/3) + f (1/3) â‰¥ t*(f (2/3) - 2*f (1/3) + f 0))
    (IsConvex_def : âˆ€ f, IsConvex f â†” âˆ€ u âˆˆ T, âˆ€ v âˆˆ T, âˆ€ s âˆˆ T, f (s*u + (1 - s)*v) â‰¤ s*(f u) + (1 - s)*(f v))
    (hS : S = fun t : â„ => {f : â„ â†’ â„ | (âˆ€ x âˆˆ T, f x â‰¥ 0) âˆ§ StrictMonoOn f T âˆ§ IsConvex f âˆ§ ContinuousOn f T âˆ§ P t f})
    (t : â„) (ht : t â‰¥ 0) :
    ((fun t : â„ => 1 â‰¥ t) : â„ â†’ Prop ) t â†” (âˆ€ f âˆˆ S t, âˆ€ g âˆˆ S t, f * g âˆˆ S t) :=

informal_statement: If $a$, $b$, and $c$ are real numbers satisfying $0 < a < b < c$, at what points in the set $$\{(x, y, z) \in \mathbb{R}^3 : x^b + y^b + z^b = 1, x \ge 0, y \ge 0, z \ge 0\}$$ does $f(x, y, z) = x^a + y^b + z^c$ attain its maximum and minimum?
informal_solution: $f$ attains its maximum at $\left(x_0, (1 - x_0^b)^{\frac{1}{b}}, 0\right)$ and its minimum at $\left(0, (1 - z_0^b)^{\frac{1}{b}}, z_0\right)$, where $x_0 = \left(\frac{a}{b}\right)^{\frac{1}{b-a}}$ and $z_0 = \left(\frac{b}{c}\right)^{\frac{1}{c-b}}$.

informal_statement: $n$ great circles on the sphere are in general position (in other words at most two circles pass through any two points on the sphere). How many regions do they divide the sphere into?

theorem putnam_1964_b4
    {n : â„•} (hn : 0 < n)
    -- `C` is a collection of `n` great circles on the sphere, i.e a collection of sets
    (C : Fin n â†’ Set (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 3)))
    --together with a collection of `n` normal vectors `v`
    (v : Fin n â†’ EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 3))
    -- A great circle `C` is the intersection of a plane `{x | x Â· v = 0}` with `S`
    (hv : âˆ€ i, C i = Metric.sphere 0 1 âˆ© {x : EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 3) | âŸªv i, xâŸ«_â„ = 0 })
    --all the `v_i`'s are non-zero
    (hv' : âˆ€ i, v i â‰  0)
    -- The circles in `C` are in general position
    (hTâ‚‚ : âˆ€áµ‰ (x âˆˆ Metric.sphere 0 1) (y âˆˆ Metric.sphere 0 1),
      (Finset.univ.filter (fun i => {x, y} âŠ† (C i))).card â‰¤ 2)
    -- The predicate that a set `R âŠ† â„Â³` is a region bounded by the collection of circles
    (IsRegion : Set (EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 3)) â†’ Prop)
    -- We can determine the points `x` in such a region by looking at the sign of their dot product
    -- with `n i` for `i : Fin n`
    (IsRegion_def : âˆ€ R, IsRegion R â†” R.Nonempty âˆ§ âˆƒ sign : Fin n â†’ SignType, (âˆ€ i, sign i â‰  0) âˆ§
      R = Metric.sphere 0 1 âˆ© {x : EuclideanSpace â„ (Fin 3) | âˆ€ i, signHom âŸªv i, xâŸ«_â„ = sign i}) :
    {R | IsRegion R}.ncard = ((fun n => n^2 - n + 2) : â„• â†’ â„• ) n :=

informal_statement:
Let $n$ be a positive integer. Let $a,b,x$ be real numbers, with $a \neq b$, and let $M_n$ denote the $2n \times 2n$ matrix whose $(i,j)$ entry $m_{ij}$ is given by
\[
m_{ij}=\begin{cases}
x & \text{if }i=j, \\
a & \text{if }i \neq j\text{ and }i+j\text{ is even}, \\
b & \text{if }i \neq j\text{ and }i+j\text{ is odd}.
\end{cases}
\]
Thus, for example, $M_2=\begin{pmatrix} x & b & a & b \\ b & x & b & a \\ a & b & x & b \\ b & a & b & x \end{pmatrix}$. Express $\lim_{x \to a} \det M_n/(x-a)^{2n-2}$ as a polynomial in $a$, $b$, and $n$, where $\det M_n$ denotes the determinant of $M_n$.

(npos : n > 0)
(aneb : a â‰  b)
(hMn : Mn = fun x : â„ => fun i j : Fin (2 * n) => if i = j then x else if Even (i.1 + j.1) then a else b)
(hpolyabn : polyabn 0 = a âˆ§ polyabn 1 = b âˆ§ polyabn 2 = n)
: Tendsto (fun x : â„ => (Mn x).det / (x - a) ^ (2 * n - 2)) (ğ“[â‰ ] a) (ğ“ (MvPolynomial.eval polyabn ((MvPolynomial.X 2) ^ 2 * ((MvPolynomial.X 0) ^ 2 - (MvPolynomial.X 1) ^ 2) : MvPolynomial (Fin 3) â„ ))) :=

informal_statement:
Functions $f,g,h$ are differentiable on some open interval around $0$
and satisfy the equations and initial conditions
\begin{gather*}
f' = 2f^2gh+\frac{1}{gh},\quad f(0)=1, \\
g'=fg^2h+\frac{4}{fh}, \quad g(0)=1, \\
h'=3fgh^2+\frac{1}{fg}, \quad h(0)=1.
\end{gather*}
Find an explicit formula for $f(x)$, valid in some open interval around $0$.
informal_solution:
Prove that the formula is
\[
f(x) = 2^{-1/12} \left(\frac{\sin(6x+\pi/4)}{\cos^2(6x+\pi/4)}\right)^{1/6}.
\]

(hdiff : DifferentiableOn â„ f (Ioo a b) âˆ§ DifferentiableOn â„ g (Ioo a b) âˆ§ DifferentiableOn â„ h (Ioo a b))
(hf : (âˆ€ x âˆˆ Ioo a b, deriv f x = 2 * (f x)^2 * (g x) * (h x) + 1 / ((g x) * (h x))) âˆ§ f 0 = 1)
(hg : (âˆ€ x âˆˆ Ioo a b, deriv g x = (f x) * (g x)^2 * (h x) + 4 / ((f x) * (h x))) âˆ§ g 0 = 1)
(hh : (âˆ€ x âˆˆ Ioo a b, deriv h x = 3 * (f x) * (g x) * (h x)^2 + 1 / ((f x) * (g x))) âˆ§ h 0 = 1)
: (âˆƒ c d : â„, 0 âˆˆ Ioo c d âˆ§ âˆ€ x âˆˆ Ioo c d, f x = ((fun x â†¦ 2 ^ (-(1 : â„) / 12) * (Real.sin (6 * x + Real.pi / 4) / (Real.cos (6 * x + Real.pi / 4)) ^ 2) ^ ((1 : â„) / 6)) : â„ â†’ â„ ) x) :=

informal_statement:
The polynomials $P_n(x)$ are defined by
\begin{align*}
P_1(x) &= 1 + x, \\
P_2(x) &= 1 + 2x, \\
P_{2n+1}(x) &= P_{2n}(x) + (n + 1) x P_{2n-1}(x), \\
P_{2n+2}(x) &= P_{2n+1}(x) + (n + 1) x P_{2n}(x).
\end{align*}
Let $a_n$ be the largest real root of $P_n(x)$. Prove that $a_n$ is strictly monotonically increasing and tends to zero.

(hPodd : âˆ€ n, P (2 * n + 1) = P (2 * n) + C ((n : â„) + 1) * X * P (2 * n - 1))

Bob wins if the parity of $\{k : \mbox{the number $k$ was chosen on the $k$th turn}\}$ matches his goal. For which values of $n$ does Bob have a winning strategy?
